author: By Lou Stoppard
title: Will Mandatory Face Masks End the Burqa Bans?
description: As face coverings become the rule in public spaces, attitudes about head scarves may change.
content: While face coverings are fast becoming the norm to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, visible on city streets and public transportation everywhere, the global politics that surround them are more complicated than ever — a reflection not just of this current crisis, but also of broader values and stereotypes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: The People Who Miss Our Kids
description: Teachers, caregivers and even clowns are feeling the pain of separation just as much as our children.
content: I’ve been seeing a lot of my son’s teacher lately. Not in person, of course — the lockdown means he hasn’t been to school in months. But I see her every day in the class meeting, skillfully wrangling a gang of first graders over Zoom, and it’s been a fascinating peek behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: A Little E-Commerce Has Big Ripples
description: Online shopping has changed our behavior, reordered the nature of work and challenged our cities.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Look After Our Most Vulnerable. They Make Around $16,200 a Year.
description: Are we ok with that?

content: At first glance, the streaming fitness class looks like any other: blue yoga mats against a neutral background, with ambient music and candles to set the mood. Two athleisure-clad instructors, flanked by hand weights, introduce themselves.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates

title: Why Vaccines Are So Slow
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Early news about medical treatments — like yesterday’s announcement that a coronavirus vaccine has shown positive results in eight people — can feel both exciting and frustrating.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Trump Administration Is Reversing Nearly 100 Environmental Rules. Here’s the Full List.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn more about the president’s policies for the environment, energy and climate, and will consider the consequences of the administration’s strategy.
content: Featured Article: “The Trump Administration Is Reversing Nearly 100 Environmental Rules. Here’s the Full List.” By Nadja Popovich, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Kendra Pierre-Louis

description: In “The Motion of the Body Through Space,” a lifelong couch potato starts running, and trouble follows.

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Suze Orman Is Back to Help You Ride Out the Storm
description: America’s favorite financial adviser was trying on retirement. Then came economic Armageddon.
content: Although Suze Orman has written more than a dozen books over the last 25 years, her favorite thing to read is people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Stevenson
title: The Commander in Chief’s Following Wanes
description: Trump started his term with strong support in America’s armed forces. But the respect the president typically gets from the military has cooled.
content: It’s widely believed that the military is predisposed to lean Republican. In 2009, even with George W. Bush’s wars in Iraq and Afghanistan looking grim, a Gallup poll found that 34 percent of active-duty personnel and veterans were Republicans, versus 29 percent Democrats; in stark contrast, among Americans who had not served in the military, Republicans trailed with 26 percent to the Democrats’ 38 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: The People Who Miss Our Kids
description: Teachers, caregivers and even clowns are feeling the pain of separation just as much as our children.
content: I’ve been seeing a lot of my son’s teacher lately. Not in person, of course — the lockdown means he hasn’t been to school in months. But I see her every day in the class meeting, skillfully wrangling a gang of first graders over Zoom, and it’s been a fascinating peek behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lou Stoppard
title: Will Mandatory Face Masks End the Burqa Bans?
description: As face coverings become the rule in public spaces, attitudes about head scarves may change.
content: While face coverings are fast becoming the norm to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, visible on city streets and public transportation everywhere, the global politics that surround them are more complicated than ever — a reflection not just of this current crisis, but also of broader values and stereotypes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul	 Sehgal
title: In Search of Time Lost and Newly Found
description: Our critic Parul Sehgal examines how the notion of time — and how we describe it — has changed during the quarantine.
content: Almost as soon as it appeared, Covid-19 seeded a peculiar and deep dread of the literature it might someday inspire. “Novel coronavirus” — in the literary sense — already conjures contempt and exhaustion, but why? What do we fear? Limp attempts at parody? Schematic sci-fi? Autofictional accounts of quarantine in Brooklyn in which the pandemic serves as backdrop to the personal epiphany of an alienated protagonist who discovers the virtues of the simpler life, via much massaging of dough and theoretical jargon? (Yes.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rina Raphael
title: Where Group Prayer Meets Group Fitness
description: In the midst of a pandemic, faith-based wellness programs have been grounding for some religious followers.
content: At first glance, the streaming fitness class looks like any other: blue yoga mats against a neutral background, with ambient music and candles to set the mood. Two athleisure-clad instructors, flanked by hand weights, introduce themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Start a No-Smell, No-Hassle Compost Box in Your Living Room
description: We’re all doing a lot of cooking right now, so grab a cardboard box and turn those scraps into nutrient-rich soil instead of smelly garbage.
content: We’re all doing a lot of cooking right now, so grab a cardboard box and turn those scraps into nutrient-rich soil instead of smelly garbage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Facing Adulthood With an Economic Disaster’s Lasting Scars
description: Those entering the job market in a downturn may never catch up in pay, opportunities or confidence.
content: Matthew Henderson couldn’t be entering the job market at a worse time. As a senior at Loyola University, he spent the spring semester interning as a trade policy analyst at the British Consulate in Chicago. But his chances of turning that opportunity into a permanent job after graduation ran headlong into the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Powell and Mnuchin Give Lawmakers Stark Economic Outlook: Live Updates
description: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
content: The U.S. economy faces irreparable damage from the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic, the nation’s top economic policymakers warned lawmakers on Tuesday, as the Congress and the White House grapple with how to restart business activity and how much additional government support is needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Cambridge University Will Hold Its Lectures Online Next Year
description: Colleges and universities around the world, confronting the coronavirus pandemic, are studying whether and how to move forward with classes next year.
content: LONDON — Cambridge on Tuesday became the first British university to move all student lectures online for the coming academic year, underscoring the far-reaching changes the coronavirus is forcing on higher education institutions around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.Y. to Let Visits Resume at Some Hospitals
description: A pilot program will cover 16 hospitals, nine of them in New York City, Governor Cuomo said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Woods Became David Berman’s Band. Then They Picked Up the Pieces.
description: The leaders of the psych-rock group helped Berman make his first album in a decade. After his suicide, they tried to get lost in finishing their own LP, “Strange to Explain.”
content: Jeremy Earl had been a father for two weeks when one of his favorite songwriters — David Berman, of the Silver Jews — emailed him with a plea: Help me make my first record in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: DanceAfrica, Dormeshia and Contact Improvisation (for One)
description: In this guide to the best virtual dance this week, a festival goes digital, and classes at Movement Research illuminate the body-mind connection.
content: The DanceAfrica experience has always been about more than just the performances gracing the stage of the Brooklyn Academy. It’s about the surrounding magic, too: the food, the street fashion (it doesn’t get better than this, anywhere) and even — don’t judge — the shopping. The DanceAfrica Bazaar, with its heady array of fabric and jewelry, is like parting the curtain to summer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump on Hydroxychloroquine
description: Readers criticize the president’s announcement that he is taking a drug viewed as ineffective and risky.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Yu Lihua, 90, Dies; Writer Spoke to ‘Rootless’ Chinese Émigrés
description: In her fiction she depicted “the struggle of Chinese immigrants in American society” — not the “Oriental exoticism” preferred by many publishers in the ’60s.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady, Katie Thomas, Patrick J. Lyons and Neil Vigdor
title: What to Know About the Malaria Drug Trump Says He Is Using
description: Here are the facts on hydroxychloroquine, which the president has promoted to fight Covid-19 despite warnings from the F.D.A. that it can cause heart problems.
content: President Trump revealed on Monday that he had been taking an anti-malaria drug as a preventive measure against the coronavirus, the same medicine that he has been promoting for two months with scant evidence of its efficacy and despite several warnings of dangerous side effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: A.C.L.U. Warns Against Fever-Screening Tools for Coronavirus
description: A report by the civil liberties group contends that reliance on thermal cameras and temperature-sensing guns to resume work at factories and offices and to encourage travel is flawed and intrusive.
content: Airports, office buildings, warehouses and restaurant chains are rushing to install new safety measures like fever-scanning cameras and infrared temperature-sensing guns. But the American Civil Liberties Union warned on Tuesday against using the tools to screen people for possible coronavirus symptoms, saying the devices were often inaccurate, ineffective and intrusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: She Spent Her Last Month of College Lifting Bodies in a Morgue
description: After her campus closed, a college senior took a job as a temporary morgue worker on the front lines of the pandemic.
content: Mariel Sander thought she would spend her final month at Columbia University going to parties, taking a modern dance class and road-tripping over spring break to five national parks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Coaches of Storied Cheerleading Team Fired After Hazing Scandal
description: A three-month investigation also found alcohol use and public nudity by students on the University of Kentucky team, the school said.
content: The University of Kentucky fired the entire coaching staff of its storied cheerleading program on Monday, saying that students on the team had engaged in hazing rituals and public nudity and used alcohol on the coaches’ watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Americans See Climate as a Concern, Even Amid Coronavirus Crisis
description: Researchers thought Covid-19 might displace climate change as a threat in the American mind. It hasn’t, according to a new survey.
content: Americans’ positions on climate change have remained largely unshaken by the coronavirus pandemic and economic crisis, according to a new national survey that showed acceptance of the reality of global warming at record highs in some categories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Woods Became David Berman’s Band. Then They Picked Up the Pieces.
description: The leaders of the psych-rock group helped Berman make his first album in a decade. After his suicide, they tried to get lost in finishing their own LP, “Strange to Explain.”

It’s about the surrounding magic, too: the food, the street fashion (it doesn’t get better than this, anywhere) and even — don’t judge — the shopping. The DanceAfrica Bazaar, with its heady array of fabric and jewelry, is like parting the curtain to summer.

title: Trump on Hydroxychloroquine

content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Strange Things Happen When You Spend a Couple of Months in Lockdown
description: “You can’t only think the Swedes are smart when it comes to pandemics.”
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I was really saddened by the death of Jerry Stiller last week, who I’ll always think of as Frank Costanza from “Seinfeld.” It got me to thinking about how far we’ve come from the 1990s, mostly for the worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Amid Hydroxychloroquine Uproar, Real Studies of Drug Are Suffering
description: The political fights around a malaria drug that President Trump says he takes daily have impeded studies into whether it works to prevent coronavirus infection or treat Covid-19 early.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s enthusiastic embrace of a malaria drug that he now says he takes daily — and the resulting uproar in the news media — appears to be interfering with legitimate scientific research into whether the medicine might work to prevent coronavirus infection or treat the disease in its early stages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Johnson & Johnson to End Talc-Based Baby Powder Sales in North America
description: The company has faced thousands of lawsuits from cancer patients who claim that its talc was contaminated with asbestos, a known carcinogen, and that the company knew of the risks.
content: Johnson & Johnson is discontinuing North American sales of its talc-based baby powder, a product that once defined the company’s wholesome image and that it has defended for decades even as it faced thousands of lawsuits filed by patients who say it caused cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Lam Yik Fei
title: Amid Pandemic, Finding Normalcy in the Abnormal
description: In a city that is no stranger to outbreaks, life has a way of going on.
content: HONG KONG —  Two blocks from my apartment on the western edge of Hong Kong Island, a Starbucks has been transformed into what looks like a construction zone, or maybe a strange art installation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Aimee Ortiz
title: Roe v. Wade Plaintiff Was Paid to Switch Sides, Documentary Says
description: Before dying in 2017, Norma McCorvey said she had supported anti-abortion groups only for the money.
content: Norma McCorvey, the anonymous plaintiff in Roe v. Wade, the landmark 1973 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion throughout the United States, said she had later spoken out on behalf of the anti-abortion movement only because she was paid to do so, according to a new documentary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: El Salvador Supreme Court Orders State of Emergency Suspended
description: The court’s decision came after President Nayib Bukele’s administration was criticized for an overly stringent quarantine and for showing authoritarian tendencies.
content: SAN SALVADOR — El Salvador’s Supreme Court said on Monday that it had ordered the immediate suspension of the state of emergency that President Nayib Bukele declared to stem the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 19, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, May 19, 2020.
content: An article on Saturday about the allocation of coronavirus relief funds to private and religious schools by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos misstated a school’s action on money allocated for it. The Wright Graduate University for the Realization of Human Potential was allocated about $495,000, but it did not claim it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Drifts,’ by Kate Zambreno: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Drifts,” by Kate Zambreno
content: In the summer of 2015, I was supposed to be at work on Drifts, a book I had been under contract for almost as long as I had lived in this city, renting the first floor of a shabby Victorian house in a tree-lined neighborhood so remote it was almost a suburb. The title of the book came from a feeling, and I wanted to write through this feeling. What I really wanted to write was my present tense, which seemed impossible. How can a paragraph be a day, or a day a paragraph? But I couldn’t often exist in the room, or even in this paragraph, now. I found myself always distracted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: The Foods That May Lower Dementia Risk
description: Blueberries, strawberries and red wine were among the foods tied to a lower risk of dementia.
content: Eating foods high in flavonoids — a group of nutrients found in many fruits and vegetables — may lower your risk for dementia, researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Hopeful Virus News (This Is Not a Drill)
description: Vaccine testing progresses, and Trump makes an admission: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: President Trump made his hydroxychloroquine reveal at a round table with restaurant executives at the White House on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Katherine Clemmons
title: Stranded M.L.B. Prospects Find a Backyard of Dreams
description: Seth Blair, a longtime pitching prospect, set up a practice area in his Arizona backyard and opened it to other players who did not have access to baseball facilities during the game’s shutdown. As many as 15 of them show up in staggered groups on a given day.
content: Danny Hultzen, a pitcher in the Chicago Cubs organization, was at the team’s spring training complex in Mesa, Ariz., on March 12 when he learned that all M.L.B. practices and games had been paused indefinitely because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
title: Man Who Filmed the Arbery Killing Faces Calls for Arrest
description: The man who recorded the fatal encounter is under investigation for his potential involvement in the pursuit of Ahmaud Arbery.
content: ATLANTA — A South Georgia resident’s video of the killing of Ahmaud Arbery helped spark nationwide protests and revive law enforcement scrutiny of the case, resulting in murder charges against two men who chased and fatally shot Mr. Arbery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Wilderness Wayfaring
description: What story does this image inspire for you?
content: What story does this image inspire for you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Mahoney
title: The 10 Tools You Need for Basic Home Repair
description: Our homes are getting a lot more use while we shelter in place. Here are the tools you’ll need to handle most projects.
content: Now that you’re spending nearly all your time at home, you may be noticing little things around the place that require your attention — a door that won’t close right, or a loose handrail. If you can’t wait until quarantine ends to take on these projects (or if a wobbly hinge is driving you nuts), you can tackle most home repairs with a set of basic tools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Katherine Clemmons
title: Stranded M.L.B. Prospects Find a Backyard of Dreams
description: Seth Blair, a longtime pitching prospect, set up a practice area in his Arizona backyard and opened it to other players who did not have access to baseball facilities during the game’s shutdown. As many as 15 of them show up in staggered groups on a given day.
content: Danny Hultzen, a pitcher in the Chicago Cubs organization, was at the team’s spring training complex in Mesa, Ariz., on March 12 when he learned that all M.L.B. practices and games had been paused indefinitely because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Purge of the Watchdogs
description: What a string of firings of inspectors general at government agencies reveals about presidential power.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: Five Delicious Reasons to Always Have Gnocchi in Your Pantry
description: Crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside, these little shelf-stable dumplings are easily dressed up or down.
content: Shelf-stable gnocchi doesn’t exactly recall its delicate homemade ricotta or potato cousins. And that’s a good thing. Pleasantly chewy like an udon noodle or, sure, a Gummi Bear, they’re a blank slate for speedy meals and keep for months. And, it’s worth mentioning, they’re also just fun to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Five Artists to Follow on Instagram Now
description: Rahima Gambo’s wanderings, Yoriyas’s Moroccan photo scenes, Amos Paul Kennedy Jr.’s “Pile of Bricks,” Slavs and Tatars’ archival gems, Vanessa Bell’s Buenos Aires.
content: A few weeks ago, I recommended Instagram feeds of artists mostly based in New York City. We were just getting accustomed to the new state of affairs, and it felt invigorating, in the suddenly compacted experience of lockdown, to take in multiple perspectives on local reality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jesus, the Beatles and … Masa Son?
description: The SoftBank chief made some eye-opening arguments to justify his company’s poor investment performance.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Why Obsess Over Expectations?’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Barbecue. Introduction, joke, smile. Friend request, message sent. First date: loud restaurant, easy conversation. Second date: “Sushi?” Who cares if I’ve never eaten it; I’ll try it for you. Third date: meeting your friends. I’m not too social, but for you I’ll try to be. “This isn’t serious,” I say. “This isn’t serious,” we say. One, two, three, four, five years pass. “This still isn’t serious.” Who wants to be serious? Still don’t know what to expect, but why obsess over expectations? I will still try everything new for you. Because I love you. — Aleks Fedoriw
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: How to Have a Fun Conversation Again
description: Coronavirus doesn’t have to put a damper on every personal interaction. Here are some tips to liven up your phone calls and text messages.
content: When you don’t leave your house for days on end, it can be challenging to be a dazzling conversationalist when friends and family call. Anytime someone asks me what’s new lately, my mind goes blank. Looking around for inspiration, I usually mumble something about the weather. There’s also a lot of heavy sighing on my end, which isn’t particularly entertaining for the other person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy’s Great Beautification: Hair Salons Are Back
description: The coronavirus pandemic has shown just how important personal grooming is to many around the world.
content: ROME — As Italy further loosened Europe’s first lockdown against the coronavirus and allowed restaurants, bars, churches and stores to open, Lucilla Vettraino went directly to her hair salon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A vaccine produced by Moderna appeared to be safe and effective in its first human trial.
content: We got an encouraging report on Monday about the first coronavirus vaccine to be tested in people, and not just in the lab. The manufacturer said the vaccine appeared to be safe and able to stimulate an immune response in a Phase 1 trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From a Rock Memoir to Chinese Surrealism
description: A selection of recent books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: HOLLYWOOD PARK: A Memoir, by Mikel Jollett. (Celadon, $27.99.) This memoir, by the lead singer of the indie band the Airborne Toxic Event, is far from your standard rock autobiography, and no wonder: Jollett was born into a violent cult and overcame a chaotic youth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lidija Haas
title: For This Lesbian Romance, World War II Is Just One Complication
description: Dola de Jong’s 1954 novel “The Tree and the Vine” is a portrait of two women dogged by issues too personal to be defined by political catastrophe.
content: THE TREE AND THE VINE
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott
title: When Barbra Streisand and Ryan O’Neal Went Screwball
description: Our critics and readers packed up their plaid valises and fled the doldrums of the present for the loony-tune streets of San Francisco circa 1972 and “What’s Up, Doc?”
content: In 1971, while watching a rough cut of Peter Bogdanovich’s “The Last Picture Show,” Barbra Streisand turned to a studio executive and said: “I want him.” What Babs wants, Babs apparently gets, which is how Bogdanovich ended up directing “What’s Up, Doc?” and we ended up laughing through it for our latest Weekend Watch Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Saw Nang
title: Raids Reveal Massive Fentanyl Production in Myanmar
description: China’s crackdown on makers of the drug, which has fueled the U.S. opioid crisis, may have simply created opportunities for crime syndicates elsewhere.
content: BANGKOK — The jungle-covered hills of Shan State in Myanmar might seem an unlikely outpost along global trade routes. But it is the remote region, wracked by ethnic conflict and undisturbed by normal policing, where much of the world’s synthetic drug trade originates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live: Oregon State Primary Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results and maps from the Oregon primary election.
content: Detailed results and maps from the Oregon primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Taylor Lorenz
title: The Hot New Thing in Clubby Silicon Valley? An App Called Clubhouse
description: For all the high-minded talk among techies, their new favorite app is an invite-only (so far) social network for mingling with one another.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Andreessen, a Silicon Valley investor, published a rallying cry last month that quickly ricocheted around the tech industry. In it, he placed the blame for America’s dismal response to the coronavirus on “smug complacency, this satisfaction with the status quo and the unwillingness to build.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: How Will Cities Survive the Coronavirus?
description: They could take a long time to recover — and may look very different when they do.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Is Slowly Reopening. It’s Complicated.
description: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom laid out new criteria for counties that hope to reopen faster than the state. There was good news for sports lovers.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Schellenberg Johnson, M.D
title: The Time for ‘The Talk’ Is Now
description: During the Covid-19 pandemic, it’s critical to discuss end-of-life plans before you get sick.
content: As a palliative care doctor in the Covid-19 era, I meet many families struggling to make decisions for loved ones who become too sick, too fast, to make their own health care choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Coronavirus Shutdowns Weigh on Book Sales
description: Total U.S. sales in March were down 8.4 percent to $667 million, a sign of how the early days of the pandemic hurt booksellers and publishers.
content: When the coronavirus spread across the United States this spring, most of the entertainment industry went into hibernation, as movie theaters, concert halls, museums, Broadway and film production sets shut down. Publishing, however, seemed more resilient: Books remained available online and stand apart as an art form that can be easily produced and consumed in isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: For Boris Johnson, Parliament Is Becoming a House of Horrors
description: In a mostly empty chamber, the blustery prime minister is sorely missing the usual whoops and catcalls as he is picked apart by the lawyerly new opposition leader, Keir Starmer.
content: LONDON — For Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, debating in Parliament used to be a raucous affair, as backbenchers from his Conservative Party hollered and whooped, booing his rivals and cheering him on like a classmate in a schoolyard brawl. These days, to his evident chagrin, it is more like a legal deposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Taylor Lorenz
title: The Hot New Thing in Clubby Silicon Valley? An App Called Clubhouse
description: For all the high-minded talk among techies, their new favorite app is an invite-only (so far) social network for mingling with one another.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Andreessen, a Silicon Valley investor, published a rallying cry last month that quickly ricocheted around the tech industry. In it, he placed the blame for America’s dismal response to the coronavirus on “smug complacency, this satisfaction with the status quo and the unwillingness to build.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $3.25 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Team Owners Enhance Rooney Rule, but Stop Short of Incentives
description: Tuesday’s vote will prevent teams from blocking assistant coaches and executives who plan to interview for new jobs. But team owners tabled a measure to upgrade the draft status of franchises that hire nonwhite candidates for leadership positions.
content: After years of criticism about the lack of minorities in top coaching and player personnel positions, the N.F.L.’s 32 owners on Tuesday took steps to increase racial diversity in the league’s leadership ranks but stopped short of adopting the most aggressive measure under consideration, which would have tied hiring to draft slots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: CBS Courts Advertisers Virtually, With a Zinger From Stephen Colbert
description: Instead of celebrities and sizzle reels at Carnegie Hall, the network presents its wares in videos sent to ad buyers.
content: Every spring CBS parades its stars and executives across the Carnegie Hall stage to try to persuade advertisers to buy commercial time during an event filled with scripted banter and sizzle reels. This year, ad buyers working from home clicked on a link that led them to a cartoon of Stephen Colbert interviewing a dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Saw Nang
title: Raids Reveal Massive Fentanyl Production in Myanmar
description: China’s crackdown on makers of the drug, which has fueled the U.S. opioid crisis, may have simply created opportunities for crime syndicates elsewhere.
content: BANGKOK — The jungle-covered hills of Shan State in Myanmar might seem an unlikely outpost along global trade routes. But it is the remote region, wracked by ethnic conflict and undisturbed by normal policing, where much of the world’s synthetic drug trade originates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: For Boris Johnson, Parliament Is Becoming a House of Horrors
description: In a mostly empty chamber, the blustery prime minister is sorely missing the usual whoops and catcalls as he is picked apart by the lawyerly new opposition leader, Keir Starmer.
content: LONDON — For Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, debating in Parliament used to be a raucous affair, as backbenchers from his Conservative Party hollered and whooped, booing his rivals and cheering him on like a classmate in a schoolyard brawl. These days, to his evident chagrin, it is more like a legal deposition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live: Oregon State Primary Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results and maps from the Oregon primary election.
content: Detailed results and maps from the Oregon primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: The End of ‘Who Me? For V.P.?’ Politics
description: Maybe now people can actually admit their ambitions.
content: WASHINGTON — Politics has always abided by certain unwritten rules. Not all of them make sense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Emulating Democrats, G.O.P. Ties House Hopes to Diverse Recruits
description: “We need candidates other than boring old white people”: House Republicans are betting on a group of diverse candidates with compelling biographies to help them reclaim lost seats.
content: WASHINGTON — When Representative Mike Garcia of California was sworn in as a member of Congress on Tuesday, it marked more than just the addition of another Republican to the ranks of the minority party in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Why Clean Shirts Become the Stuff of Dirty Laundry
description: Government watchdogs say skirting the rules against subordinates doing chores hints at a broader disregard for ethics restrictions.
content: When it comes to airing dirty laundry in Washington, dry-cleaning abuse has to be near the top of the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Election Watchdog, Dormant for Months, Can Finally Move Into Action
description: With the confirmation of James E. Trainor III, the Federal Election Commission can function again. But warring ideologies among its members raise questions about what it can accomplish.
content: WASHINGTON — Even before the coronavirus pandemic hit the United States and forced millions of Americans to stay at home, the top floor of the Federal Election Commission was quiet. Three of the six commissioners’ offices sat empty. Stacks of green paper accumulated, detailing hundreds of enforcement matters on which the agency was powerless to act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Authorities Seek Forfeiture of Ancient Gilgamesh Tablet From Hobby Lobby
description: The “Gilgamesh Dream Tablet” was displayed at the Museum of the Bible in Washington until the authorities seized it in 2019.
content: Federal prosecutors moved on Monday to formally confiscate a rare cuneiform tablet that bears part of the Epic of Gilgamesh, one of the world’s oldest works of literature, from a Bible-themed museum founded in part by the president of the crafts retailer Hobby Lobby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Jamison
title: When the World Went Away, We Made a New One
description: I lost many things during the quarantine. But there can be an unexpected abundance inside a state of loss.
content: I lost many things during the quarantine. But there can be an unexpected abundance inside a state of loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Is Slowly Reopening. It’s Complicated.
description: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom laid out new criteria for counties that hope to reopen faster than the state. There was good news for sports lovers.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan E. Rice
title: Trump Is Playing the China Card. Who Believes Him?
description: He attacks Joe Biden to deflect blame for his terrible handling of Covid-19 and record of appeasing Beijing.
content: There is a long history of American presidential candidates using China as a campaign cudgel — from Bill Clinton blasting President George H.W. Bush in 1992 for dealing with a Chinese premier known as the “Butcher of Beijing” to Donald Trump’s 2016 attack that the Obama administration had allowed China to “rape” the United States while Hillary Clinton was secretary of state. This election year, China-bashing will reach a new level, as Mr. Trump seeks to capitalize on high voter disapproval of China, Beijing’s failure to contain the coronavirus and persistent bilateral tensions between our countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth O. Ananat and Anna Gassman-Pines
title: Of the 1,000 Workers We Texted, Nearly All Are in Trouble
description: It’s not too late to help if we pass the Paycheck Guarantee Act.
content: Since 2016, Luciana has worked at Burger King clocking more than 40 hours each week. This year, she added a second job, picking up shifts at Dunkin’ Donuts. Even in the best of times she struggled to pay the bills given her low hourly wage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Too Big to Fail: The Entire Private Sector
description: Large parts of financial markets are now being managed by the government. Even if they don’t like it, investors must acknowledge it.
content: During the 2008 financial crisis, Wall Street banks and other big financial institutions were deemed “too big to fail.” The crisis unleashed by the pandemic has broadened that elite status to a significant swath of the American private sector.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: A ‘Hunger Games’ Prequel Focuses on an Unlikely Character
description: A teenage Coriolanus Snow stars in Suzanne Collins’s “The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes,” which is every bit as violent and jarring as the first three books.
content: Reading Suzanne Collins’s “Hunger Games” trilogy, which concluded a decade ago, was a feverish, disturbing, exhilarating, all-consuming experience. Its premise was horrible: that in the dystopian world of Panem, built on the ruins of what was once North America, young people who were selected each year by lottery would fight to the death, gladiator-style, while an enthralled nation followed along on TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haider Warraich
title: The Risks of Trump’s Hydroxychloroquine Hype
description: The evolving story of this drug represents one failure after another among government officials, physicians and the media.
content: President Trump revealed on Monday that despite warnings from the Food and Drug Administration, he said he has been taking hydroxychloroquine for about a week and a half as a preventive measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Why Did Mike Pompeo Want His Watchdog Fired?
description: His vague explanations for asking President Trump to dismiss the State Department’s inspector general don’t add up.
content: Three years in, President Trump’s vow to “drain the swamp” stands as one of his more ludicrous campaign promises. That said, his spring cleaning of inspectors general has exposed a patch of grime that threatens to make life awkward for one of his staunchest allies, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Newly Minted Artists, Facing a Precarious Future, Take Action
description: How do you get discovered in a teetering art world? Graduating students organize shows with peers, team up with dealers — and lobby for relief funds. Will they bring change?
content: For art students finishing B.F.A. and M.F.A. programs this spring, the big debut was supposed to have been the thesis exhibition. The culmination of years of work, these shows represent a shot at getting discovered by curators, dealers, collectors and critics who make the rounds at top schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fremson and Mike Baker
title: ‘An Overwhelming Tsunami’ for Food Banks Going Mobile
description: The coronavirus pandemic has created extraordinary demand for food banks around the country, but it has also brought unprecedented challenges.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has created extraordinary demand for food banks around the country, but it has also brought unprecedented challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Quietly Lowers the Temperature With U.S.
description: Despite the heated rhetoric on both sides, Iran has toned down its approach to the West on several fronts, and the U.S. has reciprocated.
content: BAGHDAD — After years of increasing tensions that nearly led to war, Iran has moderated its approach to the West, shifting from a policy of provocation to one of limited cooperation. The change reflects an effort to avoid direct confrontation with the United States that the Iranians say could benefit President Trump in the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: At Fox News, Mixed Message on Malaria Drug: ‘Very Safe’ vs. ‘It Will Kill You’
description: For two days running, Neil Cavuto has warned that a drug taken by President Trump, hydroxychloroquine, carries risks. Some of his colleagues disagree.
content: The stress of the coronavirus pandemic is testing even the closest relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Annie Glenn, Champion of Those With Speech Disorders, Dies at 100
description: Being an astronaut’s wife thrust her into the spotlight, but a stutter left her struggling for words until she found help.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Ben Dooley
title: It Took a Pandemic, but 7-Eleven in Japan Is Letting Stores Take a Break
description: The chain, so omnipresent it is considered part of the national infrastructure, has begun making exceptions to a store hours policy that it has long enforced.
content: TOKYO — On April 14 in a residential neighborhood of Kawasaki, Japan, Takehiro Shimada did the unthinkable. He turned off the lights and locked the doors of the 7-Eleven he has owned and operated for over 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Strugatz
title: How SoulCycle Got Stuck Spinning Its Wheels
description: It was the gold standard of indoor-cycling classes. Then everybody went home.
content: It could have been the battle of the bikes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Republicans to Pursue a Crackdown on Voting
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 19, 2020.
content: “It’s utter nonsense. This has been shown over and over. The continued insistence that there are material levels of intentional voter fraud is itself a form of fraud.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Much Has Your ZIP Code Determined Your Opportunities?
description: To what extent has where you were born, and where you’ve grown up, affected who you are?
content: How much do you think the quality of your education, your extracurricular opportunities, your health and your options after high school are tied to where you live? How do you think your life would be different if you grew up in another neighborhood where you had more or fewer opportunities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Summer Camps Are Going ‘Virtual.’ Parents Are Skeptical.
description: With in-person camps canceled because of the coronavirus, many are going online — but that’s not an option for some families.
content: Summer for our family has always revolved around the day camp at our local recreation center. My two kids swim, they play gaga ball, they make terrible art. They love the camp, and I do too — or at least, I love the six-hour break I get each day so that I can get work done and retain a slice of my sanity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Equivalents,’ by Maggie Doherty: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Equivalents,” by Maggie Doherty
content: In the fall of 1960, the prestigious women’s college Radcliffe, the sister school of Harvard, had announced an unprecedented fellowship program, one that targeted a ubiquitous and yet marginalized class of Americans: mothers. In the words of its founder, the Radcliffe president and microbiologist Mary Ingraham Bunting, the Radcliffe Institute for Independent Study was designed to combat the “climate of unexpectation” facing women in mid-century America. As she saw it, too many accomplished female undergraduates were giving up their dreams of becoming scholars or artists because they couldn’t see how they could do research or write a book while also managing a family and keeping house. The new program proposed to get these “intellectually displaced women” back on track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: EasyJet Says Cyberattack Stole Data of 9 Million Customers
description: The low-cost airline said that email addresses and itineraries were hacked, and that the credit card details of 2,200 travelers were revealed.
content: EasyJet, the low-cost airline based in England, said on Tuesday that it was the target of a “highly sophisticated” cyberattack that exposed the email addresses and personal travel plans of about nine million customers, and that some had their credit card details stolen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Notes From Our Homes to Yours
description: Suggestions, lists, distractions and quarantine diaries from our reporters, critics and editors.
content: Suggestions, lists, distractions and quarantine diaries from our reporters, critics and editors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Marie Pino, Navajo Teacher Who Educated Generations, Dies at 67
description: A well-known teacher, she was mourning the loss of her son to the virus when she tested positive. Then she died as well, adding to the Navajo Nation’s toll.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Rockwood
title: They Look After Our Most Vulnerable. They Make Around $16,200 a Year.
description: Are we ok with that?
content: It’s 3 a.m. and Kim Rockwood, a health care worker, is driving to her patients’ homes — even during the coronavirus pandemic — to help them take medication or go to the bathroom. She’s effectively on call 24/7. Yet she can barely make ends meet. As she explains in the above video, she’s always on the clock, and even though she loves her job, she can’t afford her own health insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: Is the Pandemic Sparking Suicide?
description: Psychiatrists are confronted with an urgent natural experiment, and the outcome is far from predictable.
content: The mental health toll of the coronavirus pandemic is only beginning to show itself, and it is too early to predict the scale of the impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Leonard Levitt, Reporter Who Riled N.Y.P.D. Brass, Dies at 79
description: His newspaper column, books and blog sought to hold the police accountable, and his reporting reopened a murder case against a Kennedy cousin in Connecticut.
content: Leonard Levitt, a journalist and author whose investigative and gossipy revelations of wrongdoing by the New York City police made him a must-read as the self-anointed conscience of Police Headquarters, died on Monday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Lacey
title: Locked in a Creative Struggle, With Rilke as Her Guide
description: Kate Zambreno’s novel “Drifts” is an inquiry into the artist’s efforts to remain productive.
content: DRIFTSBy Kate Zambreno
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Feels Like We Got the City Back for Ourselves.’
description: Travel restrictions have turned 11 overtouristed destinations into quiet, almost unrecognizable places, even for those who live there. It’s a bittersweet experience for the people we talked to.
content: For the past two months, many of the world’s most popular destinations have been shuttered to visitors, leaving monuments, museums, shops, restaurants, bars and streets almost empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katie Thomas
title: Trump to Tap New Company to Make Covid-19 Drugs in the U.S.
description: The Trump administration on Tuesday will announce one of the largest-ever contracts to bring pharmaceutical manufacturing from abroad to a new plant in Virginia.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will announce on Tuesday that it has signed a $354 million four-year contract with a new company in Richmond, Va., to manufacture generic medicines and pharmaceutical ingredients that are needed to treat Covid-19 but are now made overseas, mostly in India and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Leonard Levitt, Reporter Who Riled N.Y.P.D. Brass, Dies at 79
description: His newspaper column, books and blog sought to hold the police accountable, and his reporting reopened a murder case against a Kennedy cousin in Connecticut.
content: Leonard Levitt, a journalist and author whose investigative and gossipy revelations of wrongdoing by the New York City police made him a must-read as the self-anointed conscience of Police Headquarters, died on Monday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Feels Like We Got the City Back for Ourselves.’
description: Travel restrictions have turned 11 overtouristed destinations into quiet, almost unrecognizable places, even for those who live there. It’s a bittersweet experience for the people we talked to.
content: For the past two months, many of the world’s most popular destinations have been shuttered to visitors, leaving monuments, museums, shops, restaurants, bars and streets almost empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sona Patel
title: When Is California Reopening?
description: Here’s what you need to know about the state’s plan to reopen for business during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: California was the first state in the nation to order all residents to stay home to slow the spread of the coronavirus. On Monday, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that state health officials would relax their criteria for counties that want to reopen their economies faster, provided that they meet public health guidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Super Cyclone Bears Down on India and Bangladesh
description: Hundreds of thousands have been evacuated as Cyclone Amphan approaches, one of the region’s most powerful storms in decades.
content: NEW DELHI — A crushing cyclone barreled up the Bay of Bengal on Tuesday, heading for a swampy stretch along the border of India and Bangladesh and threatening to unleash 165-mile-an-hour winds and massive floods when it makes landfall on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Right to Privacy Extends to Foreign Internet Users, German Court Rules
description: The intelligence services cannot randomly search the digital data of citizens of other countries living abroad, judges said, in a decision welcomed by civil rights activists.
content: BERLIN — Privacy rights enshrined in Germany’s Constitution extend to foreigners living abroad and cover their online data, the country’s highest court ruled on Tuesday, ordering Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government to overhaul a law governing the foreign intelligence agency.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Oregon Election Results: Live Presidential Primary 2020
description: Detailed results and maps from the Oregon presidential primary election.
content: Detailed results and maps from the Oregon presidential primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Susan Pompeo Draws Scrutiny in Inquiry Over Dry Cleaning and Dog Walking
description: The wife of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is at the center of an investigation into whether a State Department employee was assigned to do household tasks.
content: WASHINGTON — Susan Pompeo, the wife of America’s top diplomat, said in an interview last year that she could handle the criticism that came with taking a high-profile role at the State Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: Tesla Owners Try to Make Sense of Elon Musk’s ‘Red Pill’ Moment
description: A liberal status symbol now has a founder who is moving to the right.
content: Owning a Tesla, the luxurious electric car, is a major liberal status symbol. It signals nothing more than good taste — the perfect balance of wealth with care for fossil fuels. But the man behind the brand is crafting a very different persona online that may now prove to be a challenge for his fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: ‘Way Too Late’: Inside Amazon’s Biggest Outbreak
description: A warehouse in the foothills of the Poconos has had more known Covid-19 cases than any of Amazon’s others after missing early opportunities to protect workers.
content: Therese Kelly arrived for her shift at an Amazon warehouse on March 27 to find her co-workers standing clustered in the cavernous space. They were awaiting a buildingwide announcement, a rarity at the complex known as AVP1. Over a loudspeaker, a manager told them what they had feared: For the first time, an employee had tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Belmont Stakes to Run June 20 as First Leg of Triple Crown
description: The horse race that usually goes last in a bid for the Triple Crown plans to run close to its usual date at a shorter distance and without spectators.
content: The 152nd running of the Belmont Stakes will kick off this year’s Triple Crown — not the Kentucky Derby.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Private and Public Schools: Equity Issues in a Pandemic
description: Readers discuss Betsy DeVos’s plan to share relief funds with private schools and how teachers’ unions influence remote learning.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Spot for Basque Dishes to Go Opens in the SoHo
description: Haizea pivots to a new approach, and takeout and delivery from spots offering Ethiopian favorites, pizza and tiki cocktails.
content: What does it take to open a restaurant in the midst of a pandemic? Mikel de Luis, the chef and the owner of a tiny, contemporary Basque-style spot whose opening was postponed by two months, will now test the waters, going takeout-only. “It’s been frustrating not to open,” he said, adding, “It’s time to try; people want something new.” Most of his dishes were to be small plates, but for his takeout menu, he is serving some larger dishes like roast suckling pig, duck and mushroom fideos (thin noodles), fisherman’s rice with chicken and seafood, and a substantial sandwich of Iberico ham with Roncal cheese. A mentee of Martin Berasategui, for whom he cooked at the Ritz-Carlton in the Canary Islands, Mr. De Luis is a native of Bilbao, in the Basque region of Spain. (The restaurant’s name means “wave” in Basque.) He has worked in Barcelona; Homer, Alaska; and, more recently, at Nana in Dallas, with the chef Anthony Bombaci. When it can fully open, Haizea will seat only around 10 instead of about 20 to facilitate social distancing. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Is Trump Challenging Mother Nature to a Duel?
description: He can’t beat her coronavirus.
content: On Easter, as the coronavirus was rapidly spreading, NPR’s “Weekend All Things Considered” carried excerpts from sermons from across the country. I was particularly touched by the way Presiding Bishop Michael Curry ended his talk at Washington National Cathedral, singing, “He’s got the whole world in his hands, he’s got the whole world in his hands. …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theresa Brown
title: I Accept Death. I Hope Doctors and Nurses Will, Too.
description: A lesson from hospice care might help.
content: Nurses crying. That’s what I hear from the front lines treating Covid-19 patients. A nurse will begin the shift crying and end it crying. Crying. And we are not a profession that cries easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Donald Trump Doesn’t Want Authority
description: The coronavirus crisis offered the president an opportunity to consolidate power. It turns out he only wants attention.
content: For the last four years two Western political figures have loomed particularly large in the imaginations of anxious liberals. The first is Donald Trump, notionally the West’s most powerful populist simply by virtue of the office that he occupies. The second is Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, probably the West’s most effective populist in terms of the powers he’s consolidated, the opponents he’s routed and the influence he’s claimed over his nation’s political life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: All 50 States Have Eased Coronavirus Restrictions
description: More changes took effect on Wednesday, but vast discrepancies remain as states forge ahead after shutdowns. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin warns of “permanent damage” to the economy.
content: All 50 states have begun to reopen in at least some way, more than two months after the coronavirus thrust the country into lockdown. But there remain vast discrepancies in how states are deciding to open up, with some forging far ahead of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Weisbrot
title: Lives Depend on Argentina’s Debt Talks
description: Governments won’t be able to contain the pandemic if they are forced to use scarce foreign currency to make unsustainable debt payments.
content: Argentina is currently engaged in intense negotiations with its creditors over at least $65 billion in government debt. The most important part of that negotiation, which can make or break Argentina’s economic recovery, is foreign currency debt. That is mostly in dollars, and mostly owned by foreigners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Nita Pippins, a Mother to AIDS Patients, Dies at 93
description: At 60, she moved to New York to care for her dying son. Instead of returning home, she dedicated herself to AIDS patients during the worst of the epidemic.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and David E. Sanger
title: Pompeo Declined Interview Request From Inspector General About Saudi Arms Sales
description: The secretary of state instead offered written answers. He was aware of the inquiry and the specific lines of questioning about his decision to resume the sales.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declined an interview request for the State Department inspector general’s inquiry into whether the Trump administration acted illegally in declaring an “emergency” to bypass a congressional freeze on arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, according to three people with knowledge of his actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Learned My Lesson
description: Trent H. Evans brings back a theme we haven’t seen for a while.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — As Trent Evans says in his notes below, puzzle people — solvers as well as those who make and edit them — are good people. But Mr. Evans is especially kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1945: Britain and U.S. Propose Meeting With Russia
description: Following victory in Europe, diplomats in Moscow suggested to Stalin that the “Big Three” powers meet in London.
content: FROM THE HERALD TRIBUNE BUREAU
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Abramson
title: In ‘Rodham,’ Curtis Sittenfeld Reimagines Hillary’s Life
description: In this novel, an alternative biography of sorts, Hillary strides into the history books without Clinton at the end of her name.
content: RODHAMBy Curtis Sittenfeld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: How Bike Share Programs Might Make Cycling Safer
description: Bicycle-car accidents decreased after a bike share program was introduced in Philadelphia.
content: Could bike share programs lead to greater cycling safety?
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Chiffon Trenches,’ by André Leon Talley: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Chiffon Trenches,” by André Leon Talley
content: I was born in a now-torn-down hospital on the edge of tony, affluent Georgetown in Washington, D.C. Two months after my arrival, my parents, Alma and William Carroll Talley, took me to my grandmother’s house in Durham, North Carolina, the center of the tobacco industry. My parents were young, and as was typical in Southern black households, it was decided I would live with my grandmother, Bennie Frances Davis, as my parents sought careers in the nation’s capital. I called my grandmother Mama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle and John Otis
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: House Relief Bill, Baseball, Virtual Graduations
description: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
content: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: W.H.O., Xi Jinping, Germany: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Tuesday: Patton Oswalt and ‘Stargirl’
description: The actor and comedian returns to Netflix with a new stand-up special, and a DC Comics drama series debuts on CW.
content: PATTON OSWALT: I LOVE EVERYTHING (2020) Stream on Netflix. Patton Oswalt has seen extreme highs and lows in the last few years. The actor and comedian’s first wife, the true-crime writer Michelle McNamara, died in 2016. After that, Oswalt told The New York Times, “I'll never be at 100 percent again.” A year later, he remarried and delivered a profound stand-up special, “Annihilation.” In “I Love Everything,” Oswalt takes a lighter approach. He discusses finding love again and shares existential anecdotes about buying a house and entering his 50s. One of his discoveries about aging: Breakfast has become dull. He mourns the vibrant cereal boxes displaying animal mascots that he has had to replace with “hospital white” boxes and sad beige bowls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The Military’s Travel Ban Leaves Some Families in a Financial Crunch
description: In March, the Pentagon announced restrictions on movements for service members and their families because of the coronavirus, upending plans for some in the middle of relocating.
content: Maureen Elias expected her family’s final move with the military to come as a relief. She and her husband, Dustin, purchased a house in Oakton, Va., where the Army was transferring them from California for Dustin’s final assignment as he neared the end of his 20-year career. They expected to be on the East Coast by April 1, just in time to close on their dream home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cat Warren
title: When Cadaver Dogs Pick Up a Scent, Archaeologists Find Where to Dig
description: Recent research highlights the power of the canine nose to uncover buried remains from ancient human history.
content: On a sunny summer day in Croatia several years ago, an archaeologist and two dog handlers watched as two dogs, one after another, slowly worked their way across the rocky top of a wind-scoured ridge overlooking the Adriatic Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Three Stretches to Tend to The Aches and Pains of Working From Home
description: Time to add some these to your routine.
content: On March 16, Nancy Black left her office for what she thought would be the last time. On March 19, however, she was back and ready to pilfer (with permission) parts of her office workstation. Dr. Black is an associate professor in the department of mechanical engineering at the Université de Moncton in Canada, specializing in ergonomics. In three days it was clear her home office was not going to meet her standards. So she came back and got her desktop computer, a large monitor and a desktop sit-to-stand apparatus, which lets her toggle between sitting and standing. Now she’s working from home pain-free, which is more than most of us can say as we toil away on tiny computers, sitting in our sweatpants on rigid kitchen chairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel G. Freedman
title: For Homeless Girl Scouts, It’s Not All Badges and Cookies
description: Nikita Stewart’s article about Troop 6000 landed them on the front page. Her book should lead to a bigger conversation about their struggles.
content: TROOP 6000The Girl Scout Troop That Began in a Shelter and Inspired the WorldBy Nikita Stewart
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Mother Sea Turtles Might Be Sneakier Than They Look
description: The large reptiles make decoy nests to distract predators during an oft-ignored behavior following their egg laying, researchers say.
content: The birth process of sea turtles provides some of the most endearing images in nature. Mother turtles trudge up on to the beach at night, dig a nest and lay their eggs, then haul themselves back into the ocean. Weeks later, dozens of adorable little hatchlings, tiny flippers churning through sand, scamper into the sea for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: How the ‘Call Her Daddy’ Feud Boiled Over
description: The podcast built a loyal audience. So did its hosts.
content: In just two years, “Call Her Daddy,” a raunchy podcast about sex, dating, culture and life in New York, became a cult sensation. This week, it descended into a fireball of chaos and internet drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Michael Jordan’s Game-Worn Sneakers Sell for $560,000
description: A pair of Air Jordan 1s from 1985, signed by the NBA legend, broke an auction record on Sunday.
content: Being like Mike comes with a high price tag these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How-To Books for an Age of Insecurity
description: Interested in learning how to knit your own socks, make cheese or grow medicinal herbs during your home quarantine? You’re not alone.
content: Seed companies are struggling to keep up with demand, home bakers are testing the nation’s supply of flour and yeast, and the quickest way to get a face mask is to sew your own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The Military’s Travel Ban Leaves Some Families in a Financial Crunch
description: In March, the Pentagon announced restrictions on movements for service members and their families because of the coronavirus, upending plans for some in the middle of relocating.
content: Maureen Elias expected her family’s final move with the military to come as a relief. She and her husband, Dustin, purchased a house in Oakton, Va., where the Army was transferring them from California for Dustin’s final assignment as he neared the end of his 20-year career. source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Stein and Jeff Bernier
title: ‘Not Where I Expected My Senior Year to Be’: In a Hospital Morgue
description: Coronavirus forced New York City’s hospital morgues to recruit an army of temporary workers. Two college students chronicled the grim realities and the glints of humanity they witnessed.
content: Coronavirus forced New York City’s hospital morgues to recruit an army of temporary workers. Two college students chronicled the grim realities and the glints of humanity they witnessed.
source.name: The New York Times

content: On a sunny summer day in Croatia several years ago, an archaeologist and two dog handlers watched as two dogs, one after another, slowly worked their way across the rocky top of a wind-scoured ridge overlooking the Adriatic Sea.

author: By J. David Goodman and Jeffery C. Mays
title: De Blasio’s Health Chief Vanished for Days. Is She Still in Charge?
description: Dr. Oxiris Barbot re-emerged and said she’s on the team. But one of her agency’s key functions in managing the pandemic has been handed to another city department.
content: For nearly a week, New York City’s health commissioner, Dr. Oxiris Barbot, had mysteriously vanished from public view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Lindsey Rogers Cook
title: These N.Y.C. Neighborhoods Have the Highest Rates of Virus Deaths
description: Race and income are the key factors that decide who dies from Covid-19 and who survives, city data shows.
content: New data released Monday sheds light on one of the biggest questions about the toll the coronavirus has taken on New York: Where are people dying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
title: Hasidic School With 60 Children Is Closed for Violating Virus Ban
description: After receiving a complaint, the police descended on the building in Brooklyn and discovered the students. Few were wearing masks.
content: The buses arrived early Monday to drop off dozens of children at a Hasidic school in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lauren Keiles
title: You’re Never Alone in a Dusty Apartment
description: Your dust is you, and the life outside your window, and the life of every tenant before you. Gross — but who right now can turn down company?
content: Your dust is you, and the life outside your window, and the life of every tenant before you. Gross — but who right now can turn down company?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
title: W.H.O., Cyclone Amphan, Huawei: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Nasaw
title: America’s Immigration Paradox
description: Two new books, Jia Lynn Yang’s “One Mighty and Irresistible Tide” and Adam Goodman’s “The Deportation Machine,” take very different approaches to the immigration question.
content: ONE MIGHTY AND IRRESISTIBLE TIDEThe Epic Struggle Over American Immigration, 1924-1965By Jia Lynn Yang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eugene L. Meyer
title: Pandemic Lockdown Halts Hudson Valley’s Booming Film Industry
description: Filmmakers have headed to upstate New York for two decades, using rustic locales to produce some 500 movies, but production has shut down, threatening development plans.
content: SAUGERTIES, N.Y. — For years, the Hudson Valley beckoned filmmakers looking for bucolic settings, and this year, it all seemed to be coming together. Film production in the area was on the rise, and additional studio space was planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong
title: U.S. Is Using Taiwan as a Pressure Point in Tech Fight With China
description: The Trump administration is challenging Chinese access to Taiwan’s high-tech supply chain — and, by extension, Beijing’s influence over the island it claims as its territory.
content: The Trump administration has for years sparred with China over tariff threats, technology and the terms of their trade deal. But in a pair of actions last week, the administration escalated those economic tensions in a way that comes close to touching a red line for Beijing: its contentious relationship with Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
title: Mnuchin and Powell Warn of Economic Scarring, and Offer Divergent Solutions
description: The Treasury secretary and Fed chair said economic damage could last. One prescribed rapid reopening, the other robust policy action.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States economy faces irreparable damage from the coronavirus, the nation’s top economic policymakers warned on Tuesday, although they offered differing solutions on how to ease the blow to business that has thrown more than 20 million people out of work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: He Had Picked the Last Day of His Career. Now It May Never Come.
description: The Spanish striker Aritz Aduriz seemed to have been given the perfect way to say goodbye to his 20-year career. Then the pandemic struck, and now he may just fade to black.
content: Aritz Aduriz has thought, every day, about the goodbye he might never have. It is not his first thought: That, of course, is his family, his wife and daughters, locked down with him in their apartment in central Bilbao, Spain. It is not his priority: That is hoping the deaths cease, the coronavirus crisis eases, and one day they might all be able to go outside again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden Calls Out ‘Anti-Semitism’ on the Left and Criticizes Israeli Policies
description: “Criticism of Israel’s policy is not anti-Semitism,” the former vice president told donors. “But too often that criticism from the left morphs into anti-Semitism.”
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told donors on a call on Tuesday that it was important to condemn criticism of Israel that drifts toward anti-Semitism, including on the political left, even as he acknowledged that he had “gotten in trouble” for such calls in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Former U.S. Nazi Hunter Seeks I.R.S. Sanctions Against Whitney Museum
description: Neal Sher, a former federal prosecutor, filed a complaint saying the museum had mishandled protests that led to the resignation of a trustee.
content: Many anticipated some fallout for the Whitney Museum of American Art when a veteran board member, Warren B. Kanders, felt compelled to resign last year after protesters targeted him in regular demonstrations at the museum.
source.name: The New York Times
